Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Pushing the Boundaries: Advancing the Science of Micro-Additive Manufacturing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award is to investigate the next generation micro additive fabrication science and technology to enable high fidelity, 3D printing at the micro-scale. Barriers that preclude advancements in this paradigm stem from a lack of standards for designing, modeling, and controlling new processes. This research addresses these barriers through the characterization of key design criteria, process parameters, and environmental conditions. These three areas provide the foundation for modeling and control laws that will improve the performance of 3D printing at the micro-scale. The educational goal is to introduce students, teachers, and parents to the intellectually diverse field of manufacturing with emphasis on the cross-disciplinary nature of the advanced manufacturing paradigm. This will be accomplished by developing interactive outreach activities and workshops tailored for families and K-12 students, integrating research findings into classroom modules for undergraduate and graduate courses, and providing research opportunities to underrepresented students.

Research results will have a direct impact on the way the U.S. manufactures functional electronics, biosensors, and optics at the micro-scale. This research aligns with national interests in manufacturing by improving the fundamental science and providing the enabling tools for advancing 3D printing technology at the micro-scale. 3D printing can be used as a low-cost, flexible alternative for fabrication without a cleanroom environment. Educational initiatives and outreach programs will recruit, educate, and retain the next generation of manufacturing engineers through a unique interactive program conducted in collaboration with local science and technology museums. The research results will be disseminated through publications aimed at reaching local, national, and international audiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Advancements in manufacturing have become more critical over the past several years as the paradigm for smarter and more intelligent systems that can provide flexible and agile manufacturing has evolved. For example, the COVID pandemic has highlighted the need for more flexible manufacturing systems that can adapt to changing customer needs, environmental conditions, and product variability. Importantly, additive manufacturing (AM) can play an important role in this transformation. However, the true impact of AM has been hindered by the lack of robustness and yield within these processes. A significant factor in these limitations stems from a lack of understanding and mathematical modeling of the physics that govern many of these processes, as well as the identification and integration of feasible sensing systems to monitor performance, and the development of control frameworks that take into consideration the unique needs and requirements within AM processes.

The research conducted during this award has provided a pathway towards integrated modeling and control for AM processes that will enable faster and more reliable additive manufacturing for a variety of applications. New control framework that are specifically tailored to AM conditions and constraints have been developed. These results have been disseminated through several journal and control publications, and a broad range of invited talks. The students and PI associated with this award have developed learning modules that have been integrated into workshops in collaboration with the Ann Arbor Hands on Museum for outreach and extensional learning opportunities for kids. Additionally, the PI incorporated salient research contributions into hands-on case studies within her undergraduate and graduate courses at the University of Michigan.
